content.description:
Start by climbing an easy crack system with varied gear to a bulge.  Surmount the bulge directly or bypass the difficulties to the right on easier terrain.  Either way puts you at a stance below an imposing overhang.  Clip a bolt (the only one on the route), and make a long reach to gain the flake above.  Continue enjoyably up the steep flake to a stance, then climb up and right to the chains.

This route is located 25 meters to the right of Matt's Route.  It is easily identified by the large overhang with a beatiful flake.
Standard rack up to #3 camalot.  Save a #1 for the flake, as I couldn't get anything else to fit.

Overhanging climbing to a dihedral, then more overhang to the anchors.

Furthest right bolted line.
4 bolts

This route makes more sense as a single pitch, but there is a difficult move at 2/3 height directly above a ledge.  For that reason (as far as I can tell), there are anchors on the ledge so you can safely commit to the move off the ledge.

Scramble easily up the slab, clipping a couple of bolts before the handholds get smaller and the feet disappear.  Delicately make your way up the next 3 meters before the climbing eases off and you can scramble to the ledge.  Either stop here to belay, or continue up and left towards the upper dihedral.  Fun climbing on steep rock past a few more bolts will deposit you at the anchors.

The bolted slab 75 meters right of the Seamstress.
Quickdraws, plus a long sling for the intermediate anchors if doing as one pitch.

From the start, climb up a series of horizontal and vertical cracks ranging from finger to fist sized. Chains are located on the face right of a vertical crack.



Start is hidden behind some trees climbers right of Squirmish and left of Caesar Salad. The chains are easily identifiable from the top and can be top roped (use your own gear).

Standard Trad Rack to 3"

Crux is low at the start with a second crux after the 4th bolt. 

Climbers right of "warm up 11a" start in dihedral to the left of the arete at the end of this portion of the wall.

7 bolts plus anchors.

Update: bolts have been chopped as of April 2021. Only anchors.

Route starts over water. Anchors installed for comfortable hanging belay. first bolt requires stick clip for safety. We don't want the climber falling in the water. 7 bolts plus anchors. Equipped  05/30/2020 Large log moved into position under the start to avoid having to Rappel into the route or wade in the water. 06/04/2020 from the southern edge of the crag, follow the shoreline north to the end  of the first accessible wall just past "seamstress".
At this point walk on a log to reach the belay station equipped with anchors for a comfortable stance. Bolts

Should be a classic once it’s cleaned and seen some action. Recommend the use of an alpine draw on the hanger below the perma-draw to reduce rope drag.

Starts on the very end of the log anchored below the wall.
8 hangers, 1 perma-draw, anchors at the top.

The first half of this route is called Crackers (5.7 PG). It is protected with traditional gear which is good through the crux. The second half is correct (Pockets are Good, sport climb) but had an original grade of 5.9. If you don't have a trad rack then you can reach Pockets are Good by climbing the first pitch of Desperado.


Starts a few meters right of Desperado below a very shallow left facing corner.
None, then bolts.

One of Ontario's best 5.12's. crack, to overhang to slab climbing. Packs a punch. the biggest line, obvious. 10 bolts & anchors.
as of 2016 the anchors on this route are rendered unusable. (Needs retrobolting)

New anchor rings installed as of June 4, 2020

Start on the right crack and follow to a ledge, climb a slightly overhung ledge to gain the first bolt, follow a rail up to the second bolt and place gear as you climb through the off-width to the anchors. 



Shares the start with Bow and Arrow but moves right at the overhang.

Mixed gear, standard Ontario trad rack to 3", couple of sport draws for the bolts, alpine draw might reduce rope drag.

climbs.name: This is what you want, this is what you get

content.description:
Start just right of the drip on good rock, move upwards on good rock cracks until it's possible to traverse left onto the hanging ice drip. The crux of the route will be moving from the rock onto the ice face. The mixed climbing might be bypassed by a talented (i.e. - skinny pillars) ice climber, or if conditions allow ice to form to the base.



Shares a start with the trad route "Johnson (5.9)"; which is on the adjacent wall, climbers right of "Squirmish (5.11-)".

Standard trad rack to 3", standard ice rack.

While this isn't a warmup for most, it's definitely a classic.  This route has a lot to offer: tricky face moves, juggy overhangs, and some spicy sections to keep you on your toes.

Getting to the high first bolt requires difficult climbing above a bad landing.  Consider a stick clip.

Start atop a boulder and make your way left with an interesting sequence below a roof.  Pull the small roof at it's left side to easier climbing up a quartzy dihedral.  A mantle move and a few bolts later, you'll find yourself below a larger roof.  Continue up through the roof, and establish yourself on the face above (crux).  The hard climbing is over, so gun it for the chains before the pump clock runs out!!  If you blow it here, you'll be going for a ride!

20 meters right of the Seamstress below a section of golden rock with orange lichen.
Quickdraws

Sunny, on the water. 
 Granite and quiet, never busy.
